thread.title: Treasury yields fall on post-jobs report rally
thread.title_full: Treasury yields fall on post-jobs report rally - MarketWatch

author: By     Ellie Ismailidou
title: Treasury yields fall on post-jobs report rally
text:
Treasury yields fell Thursday after the U.S. Labor Department said that hiring picked up in June but wages were flat and job gains in the prior two months were cut.
A jobless claims report also showed that the number of people who applied for U.S. unemployment benefits rose in late June to a five-week high.
The reports sparked a rally in the Treasury market, as investors took the news as an indication that the data-dependent Federal Reserve could use the report as cause to delay the first interest-rate increase in nearly a decade toward the end of 2015.
Expectations that a rate hike would be delayed lifted appetite for Treasury bonds and pushed prices higher, driving yields lower. Meanwhile stocks also edged higher and the dollar traded lower against its main rivals.
“The number keeps rate-hike expectations roughly balanced between September and December,” predicts James Ong, a portfolio manager at Invesco.
“The headline jobs number is good, but the flat wage growth indicates that the Fed’s 2% inflation target is not likely to materialize anytime soon,” Ong added.
“It’s not a horror show, but is on the soft side, all things considered,” David Ader, head of government bond strategy at CRT Capital Group, said in a note.
Thursday’s price action wraps up the holiday-shortened week, as U.S. markets will be closed on Friday in observance of the July Fourth holiday.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury TMUBMUSD10Y, -2.05% fell 4.1 basis point to 2.377%, according to Tradeweb.
The two-year yield TMUBMUSD02Y, -7.99% declined 4.7 basis points to 0.641% and the yield on the 30-year TMUBMUSD30Y, -1.09% Treasury fell two basis points to 3.173%.
Meanwhile, investors all over the world continued to nervously watch Greece’s negotiations with its creditors, as the country prepares for a July 5 referendum on its bailout, which is expected to be a close vote.
Read: Greek debt crisis: Latest news.
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras called on Greeks to vote “no,” saying that a negative vote does not mean an exit from the euro.
European stocks swung between small gains and losses , while yields in the eurozone yields rose, after rallying earlier this week. On Thursday, the yield on the German 10-year TMBMKDE-10Y, +4.82% known as the bund, rose 4.1 basis points to 0.815%.
The Greek 10-year yield fell 36.4 basis points to 14.840%, after rising a total of 440.1 basis points earlier this week.
